Cite this: J. Mater. Chem. A, 2019, 7, 14380
Received 21st April 2019 Accepted 21st May 2019
DOI: 10.1039/c9ta04163j
rsc.li/materials-a
14380 | J. Mater. Chem. A, 2019, 7, 14
in the hybrids of transition metals/ carbon for electrochemical water splitting
Qi Hu, Guomin Li, Zhen Han, Ziyu Wang, Xiaowan Huang, Hengpan Yang, Qianling Zhang, Jianhong Liu and Chuanxin He *
Nowadays, hybrids of transition metals/carbon (TM/carbon) have attracted worldwide attention as efficient
electrocatalysts for overall water splitting. By virtue of their tunable chemical compositions and
nanostructures, as well as synergistic effects of TMs and carbon, TM/carbon hybrids will play an essential
role in the design and development of novel yet excellent electrocatalytic nanomaterials. As such, in this
review, we summarize the recent progress in the design and synthesis of TM/carbon hybrids with
sophisticated nanostructures and their application in overall water splitting. Our attention was focused
on three important categories of TM/carbon hybrids, namely transition metal alloy (TMA)/carbon hybrids,
transition metal sulfide (TMS)/carbon hybrids, and transition metal phosphide (TMP)/carbon hybrids. We
close this article with the challenges and outlook on TM/carbon hybrids as efficient and low-cost
electrocatalysts, thereby promoting the development of this important area.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Hydrogen, with features of a high energy capacity and zerocarbon emission, has long been considered to play key roles in future energy systems for reducing or even eliminating the dependence on fossil fuels.1–5 Currently, hydrogen is primarily produced through a route of steam reforming from fossil fuels, which could lead to the consumption of limited fossil fuels and emission of carbon dioxide. In sharp contrast, electrochemical water splitting is an environment-friendly and effective route for producing high-purity hydrogen.6–9 Generally, water splitting can be considered to contain two half reactions: an anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and a cathodic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). However, these two half reactions suffer from sluggish kinetics,10–18 leading to a large overpotential for achieving a desirable water-splitting current density. For example, commercial electrolysers for water splitting oen operate at a large cell voltage (1.8–2.0 V), much larger than the theoretical value (1.23 V).19,20 In this context, it is highly attractive to develop electrocatalysts for both OER and HER to reduce the water-splitting overpotential,21–34 thereby making hydrogen production from water splitting more energy- and cost-saving. Though Ru-, Ir- and Pt-based electrocatalysts have shown high activity for the OER35,36 and HER,37,38 respectively, the high cost and scarcity of these precious metals makes their further application unreal. To this end, signicant efforts have been devoted to developing low-cost and efficient transition metal (TM)-based electrocatalysts for the OER and HER. For
eering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen,
hina. E-mail: Hecx@szu.edu.cn
380–14390
example, TM oxides,39 hydroxides40 and borides41 are active for the OER, whereas TM phosphides,42 carbides,43 suldes44 and selenides45 possess high activity for the HER. However, to date, the actual usage of TM-based electrocatalysts for large-scale and sustainable production of hydrogen is still greatly obstructed by their poor conductivity and low stability.
As everyone knows, carbon nanomaterials (i.e. graphite and carbon nanotubes) possess excellent stability and conductivity. Therefore, integrating carbon nanomaterials and TMs into hybrids could address the above issues encountered on TMbased electrocatalysts.46–50 To this end, TM/carbon hybrids have emerged as a new family of efficient electrocatalysts for both OER and HER.50–54 Normally, these hybrids not only display the features of their individual components (i.e. carbon or TMs) but also new chemical and physical properties derived from the synergy of TMs and carbon nanomaterials (Scheme 1), thereby realizing higher activities for the OER and/or HER.55,56 These new chemical and physical properties of the above
Scheme 1 Illustration of the synergistic effect of TMs and carbon nanomaterials in TM/carbon hybrids.

hybrids render them ideal candidates for low-cost and efficient water splitting instead of precious metal-based electrocatalysts. Recently, some reviews have summarized the progress made in the synthesis of TM/graphene hybrids for electrocatalysis.57,58 However, with the rapid development of synthesis technologies for nanomaterials, many novel TM/carbon hybrids are emerging, such as carbon encapsulated TMs, hierarchically porous carbon supported TMs, and carbon network supported TMs. Therefore, it is still very necessary to summarize recent progress made in novel TM/carbon hybrids with advanced nanostructures and unique compositions.
Herein, we summarized the synthesis of TM/carbon hybrids and their performance for the OER and/or HER. To simplify our discussion, the rich variety of TM/carbon nanocomposites is classied into the following three categories: transition metal alloy (TMA)/carbon hybrids, transition metal sulde (TMS)/ carbon hybrids, transition metal phosphide (TMP)/carbon hybrids. In each category, our attention was focused on the several critical aspects including the design and synthesis strategies, the features of chemical composition and structure, and the possible synergistic effect between TMs and carbon nanomaterials (i.e. electron transfer at the heterointerfaces of TMs and carbon). Finally, we pointed out the challenges of utilizing TM/carbon nanocomposites as water-splitting electrocatalysts, and some efficient strategies to address these issues are also provided to push forward the development of this important eld.

sections.heading: 2. Reaction mechanism of overall water splitting
sections.text:
As noted above, overall water splitting involves both OER and HER. According to the different media, the reaction processes for the OER and HER can be represented as eqn (1)–(4) (* stands for an active center on the electrocatalyst). No matter in acidic or alkaline media, hydrogen adsorption is a key step in the HER (eqn (1) and (2)). As such, the free energy for hydrogen adsorption (DGH*) can be an excellent indictor for the HER activity of an electrocatalyst. For example, with the best DGH* value (approaching zero), Pt-based electrocatalysts display the highest activity for the HER. When the DGH* value is too negative, it is difficult for the adsorbed H to escape from the surface of electrocatalysts, leading to slow Tafel or Heyrovsky steps. In contrast, a too positive DGH* value results in a weak interaction of H and electrocatalysts, which is adverse for the Volmer step. Therefore, the design of optimal HER electrocatalysts relies on tuning the DGH* value. In the case of the OER, the activity of an OER electrocatalyst can be mainly determined by the ability of adsorbing *OH from the electrolyte and then producing absorbed *OOH (see eqn (3) and (4)). In other words, the value of DG*OOH DG*OH has a great impact on the activity of an OER electrocatalyst. It is well-known that the adsorption behaviour of TMs or carbon is directly linked to their electronic structures.59 Therefore, tuning the electronic structures of TMs or carbon is an effective route for enhancing their activity for the HER and OER. In TM/carbon hybrids, electron transfer always
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 2019
occurs at the heterointerface of TMs and carbon. Overall, constructing TM/carbon hybrids can modify the electronic structures of TMs and/or carbon for regulating their adsorption behaviour for reactants and intermediates of the HER and OER, thereby greatly enhancing the activity for the HER and OER.
HER in acidic media:
H+ + e + * / H* (Volmer) (1)
H+ + e + H* / H2 (Heyrovsky)or
2H* / H2 (Tafel)
HER in alkaline media:
H2O + e / H* + OH (Volmer) (2)
H2O + e + H* / H2 + OH (Heyrovsky)or
2H* / H2 (Tafel)
OER in acidic media:
* + H2O / *OH + H + + e (3)
*OH / *O + H+ + e
*O + H2O / OOH* + H + + e
*OOH / *O2 + H + + e
*O2 / * + O2
OER in alkaline media:
* + OH / *OH + e (4)
*OH + OH / H2O + *O + e
*O + OH / *OOH + e
*OOH + OH / *O2 + e
*O2 / * + O2

sections.heading: 3. TMA/carbon hybrids
sections.text:
Recently, compared with their counterpart with a single metal and not alloys, hybrids of carbon/transition metal alloys (TMAs) have displayed a higher activity for the OER and/or HER due to the promoted synergistic effect between alloys and carbon nanomaterials.60–63 In general, carbon nanomaterials not only
J. Mater. Chem. A, 2019, 7, 14380–14390 | 14381

signicantly improve the conductivity of TMs but also enhance the stability of TMAs during electrocatalysis. Besides upon tuning the physical properties of TMAs, the carbon nanomaterials oen impart chemical synergy with the TMA, such as tuning the electronic structure of TMAs or carbon nanomaterials.64,65 Especially, in hybrids of TMAs encapsulated in Ndoped graphene, the electron transfer from TMs to graphene overlayers can optimize the electronic structure of the graphene overlayers, thereby enhancing the activity for both OER and HER.49,55 As such, the hybrids of TMAs encapsulated in N-doped graphene displayed excellent performance for both OER and HER, which render them promising candidates for low-cost and efficient water splitting instead of precious metals.66 TMA/ carbon hybrids with an encapsulating carbon shell are oen prepared through the high-temperature pyrolysis of metal and carbon (i.e. organic molecules and polymer) precursors. To have good control over the growth of the carbon shell, the chemical vapor deposition (CVD) route is widely utilized for preparing TMA/carbon hybrids. For example, Guo et al. coated a few-layer graphene shell on the surface of WC NPs via a CVD route using methane as the carbon resource.67 Besides using mixed precursors of both metals and carbon, the TMA/carbon hybrids can be synthesized through a single precursor, such as metal– organic frameworks (MOFs) containing both metal and organic ligands.68
As a wonderful example, Bao's group encapsulated 3d transition metals (i.e. Fe, Co and an FeCo alloy) in nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (CNTs) via a simple chemical vapor deposition (CVD) route.69 This series of electrocatalysts was very active for the HER in acidic media, especially FeCo@NCNTs–NH (i.e. FeCo alloys encapsulated in N-doped CNTs) with a small onset overpotential of merely 70 mV vs. RHE. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations uncovered that the adsorption free energy of the H atoms on CNTs could be reduced by nearby metal clusters and N-dopants. In other words, the synergy of metals and N dopants could markedly enhance the HER activity of FeCo@NCNTs–NH. Aerwards, Bao's group constructed a hierarchical architecture comprising uniform CoNi alloys encapsulated in an ultrathin graphene shell (only 1–3 layers), which displayed a small overpotential of 142 mV vs. RHE for the HER at a current density of 10 mA cm 2 in acidic media.70 DFT calculations signied that the excellent activity was attributed to the increased electronegativity of the graphene shell induced by penetrating electrons from the CoNi core, which in turn decreased the H adsorption free energy of the graphene shell and favored key hydrogen adsorption for the HER. More importantly, they found that the graphene shell thickness had a great impact on the HER activity, and increasing the thickness of the graphene shell to more than three layers could block the electron transfer from the CoNi core to the graphene shell, thereby reducing the HER activity (Fig. 1). Therefore, the thinner the graphene shell, the higher the HER activity. Similar results were also observed for the OER.71 With strong electron transfer from NiFe alloys to the single-layer graphene shell, the electrocatalysts containing NiFe alloys encapsulated in a singlelayer graphene shell displayed an overpotential of 280 mV at 10 mA cm 2 for the OER in 1 M NaOH solution, even superior to
14382 | J. Mater. Chem. A, 2019, 7, 14380–14390
that of commercial IrO2. On the basis of the above discussion, it can be concluded that tuning the graphene shell thickness is a powerful way of enhancing the OER and HER activity of hybrids with the nanostructure of graphene-encapsulated TMAs.
Besides regulating the thickness of the graphene shell, tuning the chemical compositions of metal alloy cores is also a robust route for boosting the OER and HER activity of metal/ carbon hybrids with graphene-encapsulated nanostructures. By means of one-step calcination of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), Chen et al. craed metal/carbon hybrids comprising binary alloys (i.e. FeCo alloys) or ternary alloys (i.e. FeCoNi alloys) encapsulated in graphene layers (Fig. 2a and b).72 In order to enhance the electrocatalytic activity, they intentionally tuned the meal proportions of the ternary alloy core via controlling the amount of precursors. Corresponding electrochemical tests indicated that adding a third transition metal (i.e. Ni) to the binary alloy (i.e. FeCo alloys) core could markedly boost the OER activity. As for the HER, the HER activity of ternary FeCoNi alloys could be improved by reducing the content of Ni. As indicated by DFT calculations, controlling the chemical composition and proportion of the metal alloy core would alter the number of transferred electrons from the alloy core to the graphene shell, thereby tuning the OER and HER performance (Fig. 2c–f). Aer this work, Chen's group introduced ruthenium (Ru) atoms into the cobalt (Co) core for promoting the electron transfer from the metal core to the Ndoped graphene shell, which could enhance the carbon– hydrogen bond, leading to a lower DGH* of the HER.73 As such,
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 2019

the TM/carbon hybrids containing Co–Ru alloys encapsulated in a N-doped graphene shell displayed very low overpotentials of merely 28 and 218 mV to achieve a current density of 10 and 100 mA cm 2, respectively.
Motivated by the above excellent work, our group craed MoC2-doped bimetallic alloy nanoparticles encapsulated in fewlayer-thick N-doped graphene (denoted as NG-NiFe@MoC2) via one-step pyrolysis of hybrid precursors containing binary NiFe Prussian blue analogues and Mo6+-graed polyvinylpyrrolidone (Fig. 3a).74 As shown in Fig. 3b and c, the metal core was encapsulated in 3–11 layers of graphene. Electrochemical tests indicated that NG-NiFe@MoC2 possessed excellent performance for the HER in 1 M KOH with an overpotential of 150 mV vs. RHE at a current density of 10 mA cm 2 (Fig. 3d). However, NG-NiFe@MoC2-0 (i.e. without MoC2) displayed very low activity for the HER, suggesting the marked role of MoC2 in enhancing the HER. This may be because of the fact that the introduction
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 2019
of MoC2 into NiFe alloys could enhance the M–H strength of NiFe alloys for facilitating the adsorption of hydrogen. Besides the synergistic effect of MoC2 and NiFe alloys, the N-doped graphene shell also contributes to the HER for enhancing the conductivity and stability of the NiFe alloy core. Impressively,

NG-NiFe@MoC2 also showed a high activity for the OER in 1 M KOH to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm 2 at an overpotential of 320 mV (Fig. 3e). Detailed analysis signied that the high OER activity was also attributed to the advantageous composition (i.e. the synergistic effect of MoC2 and NiFe alloys) and advanced architecture (i.e. a few-layer N-doped graphene shell). Encouraged by the excellent performance for both HER and OER, we constructed an overall water splitting system by employing NG-NiFe@MoC2 as both cathodic and anodic electrocatalysts in 1 M KOH. As displayed in Fig. 3f and g, a watersplitting current density of 10 mA cm 2 was yielded by applying a small cell voltage of 1.53 V, even smaller than that of the precious Pt/C//RuO2 counterpart. Moreover, NG-NiFe@MoC2 possessed excellent stability duing overall water splitting without deactivation for over 10 h of continuous water splitting (insert of Fig. 3f), which can be attributed to the protective effect of the graphene shell encapsulating the NiFe@MoC2 core.
Overall, the hybrids of TMAs encapsulated in N-doped graphene are promising electrocatalysts for water splitting. The excellent performance of such TMA/carbon hybrids can be attributed to the synergistic effect between TMAs and carbon, especially the electron transfer occurring at the heterointerfaces of the TMA core and the graphene shell. Tuning the thickness of the graphene shell or the chemical compositions of the TMA core is efficient for adjusting the above electron transfer, thereby promoting the synergistic effect of TMA and carbon to achieve great enhancement of the water splitting activity.

sections.heading: 4. TMS/carbon hybrids
sections.text:
Generally, there are two common methods for craing TMS/ carbon hybrids. The rst one is the solvothermal method. In this method, carbon nanomaterials (i.e. graphene and carbon nanotubes) are oen selected as the support for controlling the growth of TMSs, and organic molecules (i.e. thiourea and thioacetamide) are employed as sulfur sources. Another method is high-temperature calcination of metal and carbon precursors in the presence of sulfur powder and organic molecules containing sulfur elements. In this process, the sulfur elements are inevitably doped into carbon nanomaterials for enhancing their electrocatalytic activity and the interaction with TMSs.75
Beneting from their unique electronic structure, MoS2based nanomaterials have displayed great potential to replace Pt-based electrocatalysts for efficient HER in acidic media.76–78 It is widely accepted that the HER activity of MoS2 is derived from the sulfur edges on MoS2, whereas the bulk part is inert for the HER.79–81 Therefore, downsizing MoS2 nanoparticles (NPs) to exposemore sulfur edges is an effective strategy for boosting the HER activity of MoS2.82,83 Encouraged by the nano-conned effect of carbon nanomaterials on metal NPs, researchers introduced carbon nanomaterials to conne and downsize MoS2 NPs, thereby exposing more sulfur edges.84–86 Moreover, carbon nanomaterials can address the issue of poor conductivity of MoS2 NPs. Therefore, with high conductivity and active sulfur edges, the hybrids of MoS2 NPs and carbon nanomaterials displayed excellent activity for acidic HER.86 In addition to MoS2 NPs, the carbon nanomaterials could also impart
14384 | J. Mater. Chem. A, 2019, 7, 14380–14390
a nano-conned effect on the MoS2 nanosheets for enhancing the HER activity.87–89 For example, Zhang et al. constructed a three-dimensional (3D) mesoporous van der Waals (vdW) heterostructure containing graphene and nitrogen-doped MoS2 via a method of two-step sequential chemical vapor deposition (CVD).90 Due to the nano-conned effect of graphene, nitrogendoped MoS2 possessed a thin thickness of three layers, which could expose more active edge sites (Fig. 4a–c). Further measurements signied that the morphology, edge, defect, interface, and electronic structure of MoS2 nanosheets were engineered all-round to achieve a large enhancement of the HER (Fig. 4d). Moreover, the resulting electrocatalysts with the 3D van der Waals (vdW) heterostructure were also highly active for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the OER (Fig. 4e–g).
Indeed, except for hybrids of MoS2 NPs and carbon nanomaterials, hybrids of Ni-, Co-, or Fe-based TMSs and carbon nanomaterials also displayed a high activity for both acidic HER and alkaline HER.91–93 In the work of Chen et al., nitrogen, sulfur-codoped graphene composites containing Co9S8 NPs (denoted as NS/rGO-Co) were craed via facile thermal annealing of graphene oxides with cobalt nitrate and thiourea in an atmosphere of ammonia gas (Fig. 5a).94 Transition electron microscopy (TEM) images of NS/rGO-Co displayed many dark-contrast metal sulde aggregates with sizes ranging from a few to 100 nm (Fig. 5b). The corresponding high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images indicated that such aggregates were composed of nanoparticles with a diameter of 3.0 nm (Fig. 5c and d). The resulting NS/rGO-Co was found to be active for both OER and HER (Fig. 5e and f). Due to the satisfying activity for

both HER and OER, they constructed an overall water splitting device by utilizing NS/rGO-Co as both anodic and cathodic electrocatalysts, which could achieve a current density of 10 mA cm 2 at a cell voltage of 1.68 V in 0.1 M KOH and 1.72 V in 1 M KOH, respectively (Fig. 5g). Based on a series of characterization studies, they thought that the high electrocatalytic activity of NS/rGO-Co was attributed to the synergistic effect between nitrogen, sulfur codoped graphene and Co9S8 NPs. In another work on the composites of rGO and Co9S8 NPs, Wang et al. realized simultaneous etching and N-doping of such composites by NH3-plasma treatment.95 Beside the positive effect induced by N-doping, the NH3 plasma could achieve surface etching on both rGO and Co9S8 NPs thus providing more active sites to enable higher ORR and OER activity. Therefore, the TMS/carbon nanomaterials are a family of excellent electrocatalysts for both OER and HER. More importantly, rationally introducing heteroatoms and constructing surface defects could markedly enhance the electrocatalytic performance of such hybrids.
Although exciting progress has beenmade in the synthesis of non-precious metal-based alkaline OER electrocatalysts, only very limited electrocatalysts performed well in acidic media. Despite being challenging, the acid OER is in great demand. For example, proton exchange membrane (PEM)-enabled acid water splitting is an efficient way of producing hydrogen, possessing advantages of a high proton conductivity for reducing ohmic loss and a low gas crossover for generating high-purity hydrogen through alkaline water splitting.96,97 However, most OER electrocatalysts (i.e. transition metal hydroxides and oxides) suffer from strong corrosion in acidic solution. As such, our group
Fig. 5 (a) Schematic illustration of the preparation of nanocomposites (NS/rGO-Co) based on Co9S8 nanoparticles supported on N,Scodoped reduced graphene oxide nanosheets. (b–d) TEM images of NS/rGO-Co. LSV curves of different NS/rGO-Co electrocatalysts for the (e) OER and (f) HER. This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 2019
craed porous N,S-doped carbon network-immobilized ultrane pentlandite (i.e. Ni4Fe5S8) NPs (denoted as P-NSC/Ni4Fe5S81000) by high-temperature calcination and subsequent acid etching of hybrid precursors containing liquid polymer-coated binary Prussian blue analogue (PBA) NPs.98 As displayed in Fig. 6a and b, many ultrane Ni4Fe5S8 NPs with a size of 3.1 0.5 nm were well-distributed on the porous carbon networks (Fig. 6a and b). Electrochemical tests indicated that P-NSC/ Ni4Fe5S8-1000 nanocomposites had outstanding activity and stability for acidic OER, such as a small onset potential of 1.53 V vs. RHE (1 mA cm 2), a small Tafel slope of 72.1 mV dec 1, and long-term stability without obvious deactivation for 10 000 potential cycles in 0.5 M H2SO4 media, surpassing those of commercial RuO2 (Fig. 6c and d). Notably, NSC/Ni4Fe5S8-1000 (without porous nanostructures) displayed nearly negligible OER activity, indicating that the porous nanostructures could markedly improve the OER activity. As uncovered by both experimental results and theoretic calculations, the excellent performance was attributed to the synergistic effect between PNSC and Ni4Fe5S8 NPs: the pyridinic-N,S doped carbon could readily adsorb water, and then the Fe sites of Ni4Fe5S8 NPs

would catalyze the absorbed water to produce oxygen gas (Fig. 6e and f). Besides this, the hierarchically porous nanostructures also contributed to the high activity thus signicantly favouring multiphase transport during the OER.
In summary, in this section, we highlighted that the nanoconned effect of carbon nanomaterials could downsize the TMS NPs and nanosheets to expose more highly active sulfur edges, which therefore greatly improved the activity of TMSs. Moreover, the activity of TMS/carbon hybrids can be enhanced by rationally introducing another heteroatom (i.e. nitrogen) and defects into the hybrids. Impressively, the TMS/carbon hybrids may be good alternatives to precious metals for acidic OER.

sections.heading: 5. TMP/carbon hybrids
sections.text:
Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) were also found to be very active for the HER. In 2015, Rodriguez et al. investigated the activity of Ni2P for acidic HER by DFT calculations,99 which signied that the (001) plane of Ni2P indeed possessed high activity for the HER, even higher than that of the Pt/C electrocatalyst. They pointed out that the introduction of P could reduce the concentration of highly active Ni sites, which causes Ni2P(001) rather than the pure metallic Ni surface to act like a hydrogenase. Correspondingly, the isolated Ni atoms and nonmetallic P atoms with a negative charge could serve as hydride-acceptor and proton-acceptor sites, respectively. As a result, the surface of Ni2P(001) possessed both hydrideacceptor and proton-acceptor sites, working together to facilitate the HER. Encouraged by the above exciting results, enormous interest has been gained in the synthesis of TMPs with different nanostructures for the HER.100–103 Aer that, TMPs was found to have an excellent performance for the OER in alkaline media.104–106 The OER activity of TMPs is derived from the in situ formed metal oxide shell on the surface of TMPs. Therefore, TMPs are a family of bifunctional and efficient electrocatalysts for water splitting. The TMP/carbon hybrids are oen synthesized using PH3 gas as the phosphorus source (derived from sodium hypophosphite) at a temperature of 300–400 C.
Like the above two hybrids (i.e. TM/carbon and TMS/carbon hybrids), coupling TMPs with carbon nanomaterials could enhance the conductivity of TMPs and modify the electronic structures of TMPs for boosting the electrocatalytic activity.107,108 For example, Feng et al. encapsulatedMoPNPs in aMo, P-codoped carbon layer (denoted as MoP@C) for enhancing the alkaline HER activity (Fig. 7a–c).109 In 1 M KOHmedia, MoP (i.e. without carbon layers) displayed a large Tafel slope of 102 mV dec 1, much larger than that of MoP@C (54 mV dec 1) (Fig. 7d). This indicated that the generated Mo–C and P–C bonds situated at the interface of MoP and carbon layers could substantially facilitate the HER. As demonstrated by DFT calculations, such interfaces tuned the band structure of MoP@C and favored fast electron transfer, accumulation, and subsequent delocalization (Fig. 7e).
It is well-known that the performance of an electrocatalyst is also related to the mass transport during electrocatalysis. Because of the complicated three-phase transport (i.e. gas– liquid–solid) during the process of the OER and HER,
14386 | J. Mater. Chem. A, 2019, 7, 14380–14390
constructing hierarchically porous structures is an effective way of facilitating mass transport during the OER and HER.110 In this context, TMPs were supported on the porous carbon to expose more active sites and accelerate the mass transport. With a controllable structure, high porosity, high surface area, and abundant carbon resources, metal–organic frameworks (MOF) are widely utilized as precursors for craing TMP/carbon hybrids with porous nanostructures.111 As reported by Lou et al. a template-engaged method was developed for transforming Ni–Ni Prussian blue analogue (PBA) nanoplates into porous carbon coated nickel phosphides nanoplates comprising mixed phases of Ni5P4 and Ni2P (Fig. 8a–c).112 Due to the desirable nanostructures and in situ formed active oxidized nickel species, the resulting Ni–P porous nanoplates displayed a much higher OER activity than Ni(OH)2 and NiO porous nanoplates (Fig. 8d and e). Moreover, the Ni–P nanoplates were also active for acidic HER. Aerwards, they synthesized carbon incorporated Ni–Co mixed metal phosphide nanoboxes (denoted as
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 2019

1 PM
NiCo–P/C) using a similar metal–organic framework (MOF)based strategy.113 Beneting from the unique hollow nanostructures, NiCo–P/C only required an overpotential of 330 mV to achieve a current density of 10mA cm 2. Therefore, MOFs are ideal precursors for craing porous or even hollow-structured TMP/carbon hybrids to achieve higher electrocatalytic activity for the OER and HER.
Herein, our group craed a three-dimensional (3D) network composed of N-doped carbon-coated core–shell NiFeOx@NiFe–P (denoted as NC-NiFeOx@NiFe–P) via phosphorization and subsequent surface oxidation of a MOF/polymer hybrid precursor (Fig. 9a).114 Notably, the polymer (i.e. polyvinylpyrrolidone, PVP) overlayers coated on the surface of MOFs could not only prevent the aggregation of the resulting mixed Ni/Fe phosphide (NiFe–P) NPs but also transform into N-doped carbon during high-temperature phosphorization, thereby facilitating the formation of a uniform 3D network structure (Fig. 9b and c). As a result, NC-NiFeOx@NiFe–P showed excellent performance for both OER and HER. On basis of detailed electrochemical tests, the high electrocatalytic activity was due to the following three aspects: (1) the well-ordered 3D network with good conductivity and more exposed active sites, favoring charge transfer during the OER and HER; (2) the active sites on both NiFe-oxide shell and Ndoped carbon; and (3) the NiFe-phosphide core affording active sites for adsorbing active hydrogen during the HER and favoring the proton transfer during the OER. Impressively, NCNiFeOx@NiFe–P could be utilized as both OER and HER electrocatalysts for constructing overall water-splitting devices to enable a current density of 10 mA cm 2 at a small voltage of 1.59 V (Fig. 9d and e).
Clearly, TMP/carbon hybrids are very active for water splitting, and the heterointerfaces of TMPs and carbon are key to their high activity. Moreover, constructing hierarchically porous structures on TMP/carbon hybrids could promote the exposure of active sites and accelerate mass transport during water splitting, thereby boosting the performance of TMP/carbon hybrids for water splitting.
cm 2. (e) Optical photograph displaying the generation of hydrogen and oxygen bubbles on Ni foam. Reproduced with permission from ref. 114, Copyright 2018, Royal Society of Chemistry.
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 2019

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, transition metal (TM)/carbon hybrids have displayed great potential as highly active electrocatalysts for lowcost and efficient water splitting. In this contribution, we have attempted to summarize the recent progress made in the synthesis of TM/carbon hybrids with controllable chemical compositions and advanced nanostructures, as well as their performance for electrochemical water splitting. According to the different chemical compositions of metals, the TM/carbon hybrids were classied into three sorts, namely transition metal alloy (TMA)/carbon hybrids, transition metal sulde (TMS)/carbon hybrids, and transition metal phosphide (TMP)/ carbon hybrids. Notably, in these hybrids, the carbon
J. Mater. Chem. A, 2019, 7, 14380–14390 | 14387

1 PM
nanomaterials could not only enhance the conductivity and stability of TMs but also tune the surface electronic structure of TMs, thereby boosting the activity of TMs for the OER and/or HER. In this context, the excellent performance of TM/carbon hybrids could be mainly attributed to the synergy between TMs and carbon nanomaterials. Moreover, we highlighted that regulating the nanostructures of TM/carbon hybrids was a robust strategy for enhancing the the OER and/or HER performance. For example, in the hybrids containing a graphene shell-encapsulated TMA core, tuning the thickness of the graphene shell or the chemical compositions of the TMA core could promote the electronic transfer between the graphene shell and the TMA core, thereby promoting the synergistic effect between them and enhancing the activity for the OER and/or HER. As for the hybrids of TMS/carbon and TMP/carbon, the exposure of active sites and mass transport could be markedly enhanced by constructing porous nanostructures to achieve higher OER and/or HER activity.
Despite the signicant progress made in the synthesis of TM/ carbon hybrids and their application in water splitting, the following issues remain. (1) It is well-known that carbon nanomaterials without heteroatom doping are very inert. As such, it is essential to dope heteroatoms (i.e. N, P, and S) into carbon nanomaterials to promote the electron transfer between carbon and TMs, as well as the corresponding synergistic effects. However, so far, there are still no effective routes to control the heteroatom doping process, which could make it difficult to optimize the activity of these TM/carbon electrocatalysts for the OER and HER. (2) The studies on the mechanisms of electrocatalysts are not only of great scientic value, but more importantly, they could provide important guides for the rational design and development of highly efficient electrocatalysts. However, in-depth investigations for mechanisms of TM/carbon electrocatalysts are still very few. Moreover, OER and HER tests oen lead to surface reduction and oxidation of TMs due to the large overpotentials required to drive them. And, the above in situ formed species are believed to be the actual active sites for the OER and HER. Therefore, great efforts are still required to uncover the mechanisms of TM/carbon electrocatalysts for the OER and HER. (3) At present, most of the attention is focusing on electrocatalysts for alkaline water splitting. However, the reliable polymer diaphragms for alkaline electrolysis are still unknown and need further development. Conversely, the well-established proton exchange membrane (PEM) can directly serve as diaphragms for acidic water electrolysis. Furthermore, the PEM enables a small gas crossover and a high proton conductivity for producing highpurity hydrogen and reducing ohmic loss, respectively. Therefore, some attention should be also paid to the synthesis of electrocatalysts for acidic water splitting. However, most OER electrocatalysts (i.e. transition metal oxides and hydroxides) suffer from sharp corrosion in acidic solution. We note that the carbon shell could protect TM cores from corrosion by acidic solution in the TM/carbon hybrids with carbon-encapsulated nanostructures. In this context, the carbon-encapsulated TM/ carbon hybrids may be efficient and stable electrocatalysts for acidic OER. However, reports about utilizing such hybrids as
14388 | J. Mater. Chem. A, 2019, 7, 14380–14390
electrocatalysts for acidic OER and even acidic water splitting are still lacking.

metadata.abstractText: Nowadays, hybrids of transition metals/carbon (TM/carbon) have attracted worldwide attention as efficient electrocatalysts for overall water splitting. By virtue of their tunable chemical compositions and nanostructures, as well as synergistic effects of TMs and carbon, TM/carbon hybrids will play an essential role in the design and development of novel yet excellent electrocatalytic nanomaterials. As such, in this review, we summarize the recent progress in the design and synthesis of TM/carbon hybrids with sophisticated nanostructures and their application in overall water splitting. Our attention was focused on three important categories of TM/carbon hybrids, namely transition metal alloy (TMA)/carbon hybrids, transition metal sulfide (TMS)/carbon hybrids, and transition metal phosphide (TMP)/carbon hybrids. We close this article with the challenges and outlook on TM/carbon hybrids as efficient and low-cost electrocatalysts, thereby promoting the development of this important area.
metadata.creator: Arbortext Advanced Print Publisher 9.1.510/W Unicode
